name: APT28
description: A Russian cyber espionage group believed to be associated with the GRU. Active since at least 2004, known for high-profile attacks including the DNC hack.

name: APT29
description: Another Russian group, often attributed to the SVR. Known for stealthy, long-term espionage campaigns, including the SolarWinds supply chain attack.

name: Lazarus Group
description: A prolific North Korean group linked to the RGB. Responsible for the Sony Pictures hack, the Bangladesh Bank heist, and the WannaCry ransomware outbreak.

name: APT41
description: A unique Chinese group that conducts both state-sponsored espionage and financially motivated cybercrime, often targeting the video game industry.

name: APT33
description: An Iranian group targeting aerospace and energy sectors in the US, Saudi Arabia, and South Korea. associated with the Shamoon wiper attacks.

name: Equation Group
description: Highly sophisticated group widely suspected to be tied to the NSA. Known for complex malware platforms and hard drive firmware reprogramming capabilities.

name: Sandworm Team
description: Russian GRU unit responsible for the disruptive attacks on Ukraine's power grid and the global NotPetya ransomware attack.

name: APT1
description: One of the most prolific Chinese cyber espionage groups, exposed by Mandiant in 2013 as Unit 61398 of the PLA.

name: APT32
description: A Vietnam-linked group targeting foreign companies investing in Vietnam's manufacturing, consumer products, and hospitality sectors.

name: OilRig
description: Iranian group focused on reconnaissance and espionage in the Middle East, targeting finance, energy, and government organizations.

name: FIN7
description: Financially motivated group known for stealing millions of credit card numbers. Often mimics business processes to trick victims.

name: Turla
description: Another Russian-linked group known for complex malware and using hijacked satellite internet connections for C2 anonymity.

name: MuddyWater
description: Group believed to be subordinate to the Iranian MOIS. Targets organizations in the Middle East, Europe, and North America.

name: APT3
description: China-based group attributed to the MSS. Known for the use of the Pirpi backdoor and exploitation of zero-day vulnerabilities.

name: APT10
description: Notorious for the 'Cloud Hopper' campaign targeting MSPs to gain access to their clients' intellectual property.

name: DarkSide
description: Ransomware-as-a-Service group responsible for the Colonial Pipeline attack. Known for their 'professional' business model.

name: Conti
description: One of the most aggressive ransomware groups, known for targeting hospitals and public services. Disbanded/reformed after internal chat leaks.

name: REvil
description: Responsible for the Kaseya VSA supply chain attack. Known for demanding exorbitant ransoms.

name: Wizard Spider
description: A sophisticated criminal group behind TrickBot and Ryuk. Often acts as an initial access broker for other ransomware gangs.

name: Charming Kitten
description: Iranian group known for targeting individuals involved in Middle Eastern affairs, using elaborate social engineering personas.

name: Mummy Spider
description: Operators of the Emotet botnet, once described as the 'most dangerous malware in the world'. Provides access to other criminals.

name: Wicked Panda
description: Prolific Chinese group conducting state espionage and personal profit cybercrime.

name: Mustang Panda
description: Targeting NGOs and government entities, particularly those with relations to China and the Vatican.

name: Deep Panda
description: Attributed to the Anthem health insurance breach and OPM data breach. Focuses on stealing PII.

name: Silence
description: Russian-speaking group targeting financial organizations in Russia, former Soviet states, and Europe.

name: CopyKittens
description: Iranian group targeting Israel, Saudi Arabia, Germany, and the US.

name: Magic Hound
description: Aggressive Iranian group known for high-volume spearphishing campaigns.

name: DarkHotel
description: Known for targeting C-level executives via hotel Wi-Fi networks in Asia.

name: ScarCruft
description: North Korean group focused on domestic surveillance and targeting those opposing the regime.

name: Kimsuky
description: Tasked with gathering intelligence on foreign policy and national security issues related to the Korean peninsula.

name: TA505
description: One of the most active cybercriminal actors, known for distributing Dridex banking trojan and Locky ransomware.

name: Gamaredon
description: Russian FSB-linked group focused almost exclusively on targeting Ukrainian entities.

name: Barium
description: Chinese group known for supply chain attacks against software companies.

name: Tick
description: Chinese group primarily targeting Japanese organizations in defense and technology sectors.

name: Promethium
description: Group utilizing watering hole attacks to distribute trojanized versions of legitimate software like WinRAR and TrueCrypt.

name: Neodymium
description: Advanced group using complex backdoors that emulate legitimate software behavior.

name: PLATINUM
description: Highly sophisticated group targeting South and Southeast Asia. Known for 'hotpatching' vulnerabilities to hide their presence.

name: APT19
description: Chinese group targeting legal and investment firms.

name: APT18
description: Chinese group known for high-profile attacks on US healthcare and aerospace sectors.

name: APT17
description: Chinese group known for using Microsoft TechNet profiles to host C2 addresses.

name: APT16
description: Chinese group focusing on Japanese and Taiwanese organizations.

name: APT12
description: Focused on tracking journalists and Taiwanese government entities.

name: Admin@338
description: Chinese group targeting organizations involved in international finance and economic policy.

name: Thrip
description: Advanced group targeting satellite communications and geospatial imaging companies.

name: MenuPass
description: Known for the Operation Cloud Hopper campaign affecting MSPs globaly.

name: Bronze Butler
description: Focuses heavily on Japanese intellectual property theft.

name: Emissary Panda
description: Highly active group targeting government and defense contractors worldwide.

name: TEMP.Periscope
description: Targets the maritime industry and naval defense contractors to support Chinese naval modernization.

name: TEMP.Isotope
description: Russian group targeting energy sector in Europe and North America.

name: Winnti Group
description: Umbrella term for several Chinese groups sharing TTPs and tools like Winnti malware.

name: FIN4
description: Targets confidential information about public companies to use in stock market manipulation schemes.

name: FIN5
description: Cybercrime group specializing in stealing payment card data via Point-of-Sale (POS) malware.

name: FIN6
description: High-profile cybercrime group known for massive card theft operations.

name: FIN8
description: Financially motivated group targeting the retail and hospitality sectors.

name: FIN10
description: Extortion-focused group targeting casinos and mining companies in Canada.

name: FIN11
description: Subset of the TA505 group, moved to ransomware operations.

name: Cobalt Group
description: Criminal group named after their heavy usage of the Cobalt Strike penetration testing tool.

name: Silence Group
description: Believed to be former security researchers turned cybercriminals targeting financial institutions.

name: MoneyTaker
description: Sophisticated group capable of attacking core banking systems like SWIFT and AWS CBR.

name: Magecart
description: Umbrella term for various groups injecting malicious scripts into e-commerce checkout pages to steal credit card data.

name: APT2
description: PLA Unit 61486, targeting space and defense industries.

name: APT4
description: Targeting US defense industrial base.

name: APT5
description: Focuses on telecommunications and technology companies.

name: APT6
description: Historical group targeting transportation and engineering sectors.

name: APT7
description: Focus on construction and engineering firms.

name: APT8
description: Targeting media and entertainment organizations.

name: APT9
description: Focused on healthcare and pharmaceutical intelligence.

name: APT14
description: Satellite and maritime communications targeting.

name: APT15
description: Targeting oil, military, and diplomatic entities.

name: APT20
description: China-based group utilizing stolen VPN credentials.

name: APT21
description: Targeting Russian government and Chinese dissidents.

name: APT22
description: Focused on political dissidents.

name: APT23
description: Targeting government and defense in the US and Philippines.

name: APT24
description: Compromising government and healthcare organizations.

name: APT25
description: Focuses on defense industrial base.

name: APT26
description: Aerospace and defense targeting.

name: APT30
description: Long-running espionage campaign against Southeast Asian nations.

name: APT31
description: Targeting government and financial institutions.

name: APT36
description: Pakistani group targeting Indian government and military entities.

name: APT37
description: North Korean group focusing on defectors and government officials.

name: APT38
description: Financially motivated North Korean subgroup responsible for massive bank heists.

name: APT39
description: Iranian group targeting the travel and telecommunications industries to track individuals.

name: APT40
description: Targeting maritime and defense research in support of China's Belt and Road Initiative.

name: Gamaredon
description: FSB-linked group targeting Ukrainian government and military.

name: BlackEnergy
description: Responsible for power grid attacks in Ukraine.

name: TeleBots
description: Evolution of BlackEnergy, responsible for NotPetya.

name: GreyEnergy
description: Successor to BlackEnergy, focusing on stealth.

name: Hades
description: Associated with the Olympic Destroyer attack.

name: STRONTIUM
description: Microsoft's name for APT28.

name: ZINC
description: Microsoft's name for Lazarus.

name: IRIDIUM
description: Microsoft's name for Sandworm.

name: HOLMIUM
description: Microsoft's name for APT33.

name: MERCURY
description: Microsoft's name for MuddyWater.

name: THALLIUM
description: Microsoft's name for Kimsuky.

name: PHOSPHORUS
description: Microsoft's name for APT35.

name: BARIUM
description: Microsoft's name for APT41.

name: GALLIUM
description: Targeting telecommunications providers.

name: GADOLINIUM
description: Microsoft's name for APT40.

name: BROMINE
description: Targeting government entities.

name: KRYPTON
description: Microsoft's name for Turla.
